pullrequest.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

content.raw:
Dear all,

I am having the following problem: after I successfully installed Gazebo-haptix and the octave packages, I tried to run the hx_matlab_controller.m example, octave runs this output

```
octave:1> hx_matlab_controller
error: hxgz: Expects 8 fields
error: called from:
error:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hx_update.m at line 87, column 10
error:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hx_matlab_controller.m at line 63, column 9
octave:1> 
octave:1> 
octave:1> exit
 
```
I supposed that there is a mismatching between the cmd structure in hx_matlab_controller.m and what the hx_update.c takes as input.

thank you in advance for any suggestion
content.html:
Dear all,

I am having the following problem: after I successfully installed Gazebo-haptix and the octave packages, I tried to run the hx_matlab_controller.m example, octave runs this output

octave:1> hx_matlab_controller
error: hxgz: Expects 8 fields
error: called from:
error:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hx_update.m at line 87, column 10
error:   /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave/hx_matlab_controller.m at line 63, column 9
octave:1> 
octave:1> 
octave:1> exit

I supposed that there is a mismatching between the cmd structure in hx_matlab_controller.m and what the hx_update.c takes as input.

thank you in advance for any suggestion

pull_request.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

update.description:
Match the [spec](#!/osrf/haptix_api/pull-request/5).

Consolidate mex calls into one .mex file, to avoid potential problems with
memory management inside MATLAB. Add .m files to contain help and also
dispatch to the right function inside the common .mex file. Implement
and start using hx_last_result() to access error strings. Update example
MATLAB and C controllers to match new API.
update.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

content.html: Thanks. I went ahead and made the path changes you suggested. Time to merge.

pull_request.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

pullrequest.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

content.raw:
To test this change on Linux with octave:

    # Ensure that you're up to date on handsim/default
    gazebo worlds/arat.world &
    sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev
    make install
    cd <install>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave
    # Ensure that <install>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu is in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH
    octave

Now you can call things like `hx_robot_info` and `hx_read_sensors`.  Or `help hx_connect`.  You can also try the example controller, `hx_matlab_controller`.
content.html:
To test this change on Linux with octave:

# Ensure that you're up to date on handsim/default
gazebo worlds/arat.world &
sudo apt-get install liboctave-dev
make install
cd <install>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/haptix-comm/octave
# Ensure that <install>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu is in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH
octave

Now you can call things like hx_robot_info and hx_read_sensors. Or help hx_connect. You can also try the example controller, hx_matlab_controller.

content.raw:
Final tests on jenkins are fine.

 * [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/55/)
 * [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/haptix/job/haptix_commt-any-devel-trusty-amd64/5/)

Consider this approved, I just leave some comments to modify paths but they are a bit offtopic on this pull request. I can resend the changes in a new one if needed.
content.html:
Final tests on jenkins are fine.

  • Windows
  • Trusty

Consider this approved, I just leave some comments to modify paths but they are a bit offtopic on this pull request. I can resend the changes in a new one if needed.

content.raw:
I'm getting this problem on my box:

```
octave:3> hx_robot_info 
error: hx_robot_info: /tmp/lala/usr/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave/hxgz.mex: failed to load: /tmp/lala/usr/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave/hxgz.mex: undefined symbol: hx_last_result
```

Is this a problem only in my end? **UPDATE: yes. I have the previous version of libhaptix installed in the system**

Is this a problem only in my end? UPDATE: yes. I have the previous version of libhaptix installed in the system

content.raw: This could happen if you are not installing haptix in system using CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=/usr. The needed .so files should available from the standard paths or you will need to use the LD_LIBRARY_PATH.
content.html: This could happen if you are not installing haptix in system using CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=/usr. The needed .so files should available from the standard paths or you will need to use the LD_LIBRARY_PATH.

content.raw:
Reviewing this, looks not very smart to installing the files directly on /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave which already have some other subdirectories. Some other options:

 * ${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}/octave/packages/haptix/
 * ${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}/haptix/octave/
content.html:
Reviewing this, looks not very smart to installing the files directly on /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave which already have some other subdirectories. Some other options:

  • ${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}/octave/packages/haptix/
  • ${CMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR}/haptix/octave/

content.raw:
From my very basic understanding of matlab, the addpath works to say octave/matlab where to locate the .m files. Current directory is automatically added to the path.

`LD_LIBRARY_PATH` sounds to me like a problem for octave to locate the binary hxgz.mex.
content.html:
From my very basic understanding of matlab, the addpath works to say octave/matlab where to locate the .m files. Current directory is automatically added to the path.

LD_LIBRARY_PATH sounds to me like a problem for octave to locate the binary hxgz.mex.

content.raw:
I made a few changes in this [branch](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/branches/compare/update_matlab_api_caguero..update_matlab_api#diff). We could deallocate the `haptixNode` in the `hx_close()` function.

I tested it on Octave and it looks good to me.
content.html:
I made a few changes in this branch. We could deallocate the haptixNode in the hx_close() function.

I tested it on Octave and it looks good to me.

pull_request.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

pullrequest.title: Update to match new MATLAB API

content.raw: I'm not an expert, but I've been running octave from inside `lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave`, to be able to locate the `.m` and `.mex` files, but also adding `lib/x86_64-linux-gnu` to `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, to ensure that, when loading the `.mex`, the required `.so` files can be found.
content.html: I'm not an expert, but I've been running octave from inside lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave, to be able to locate the .m and .mex files, but also adding lib/x86_64-linux-gnu to LD_LIBRARY_PATH, to ensure that, when loading the .mex, the required .so files can be found.

content.raw:
~~I had to put `<install>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave` in my `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`. Is that expected?~~

~~Never mind. I did something wrong. It works.~~

I really had to run this command inside octave: `addpath('~/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave')`

Or run octave from `'~/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave'`

Adding paths to `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` didn't work for me.
content.html:
I had to put <install>/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave in my LD_LIBRARY_PATH. Is that expected?

Never mind. I did something wrong. It works.

I really had to run this command inside octave: addpath('~/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave')

Or run octave from '~/local/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/octave'

Adding paths to LD_LIBRARY_PATH didn't work for me.

content.raw:
CI Results:

* [Trusty build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/haptix/job/haptix_commt-any-devel-trusty-amd64/4/console) (using octave to compile mex) is happy.
* [Windows compilation is also happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/haptix_comm-any-devel-windows7-amd64/53/).

Note that we would need to merge pull request #40 to get continuous integration with real MATLAB.
content.html:
CI Results:

  • Trusty build (using octave to compile mex) is happy.
  • Windows compilation is also happy.

Note that we would need to merge pull request #40 to get continuous integration with real MATLAB.
